case_vignette: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother for altered mental status. His mother reports that over the past month, the patient has been failing his high school exams. She has noticed reduced attention and poor memory. She has had to repeat conversations that they had only hours ago. Then this morning, the patient woke up at home confused, asking where he was. His mother states that he is normally a “bright student” and is in all honors classes. The patient was on a “delayed vaccine schedule" as a child and developed measles at age 6. Since then, he has been healthy. He has no chronic medical conditions and takes only a daily multivitamin. His maternal grandfather has Huntington disease. His temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 110/82 mmHg and pulse is 86/min. On physical examination, there is no nuchal rigidity. The patient is disoriented to time and place. His mini mental status exam score is 16/30. The mother adds that 2 months ago her son told her that he was attracted to men. She is not sure if he is sexually active. She denies recent travel. She is unsure about recent sick contacts but says he started volunteering at a local hospital 3 weeks ago and received a flu vaccination. Labs are drawn and a drug screen is pending. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is obtained, as shown in Figure A. Within 3 days of hospital admission, the patient develops unilateral, slow-myoclonic jerks.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble with my memory and attention, and I woke up this morning feeling really confused about where I was.
How old are you?
I'm 17 years old.
Do you have any family history of neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease or dementia?
My maternal grandfather has Huntington disease.
Have you experienced any uncontrolled movements or abnormal body postures?
Yes, I've started having some slow jerking movements on one side.
I see. Have you been experiencing any changes in your mood or behavior?
My mother mentioned that I've been less attentive and my memory has been poor lately.
Have you been examined by a healthcare professional for these symptoms?
Yes, I've been to the emergency room and had a physical examination.
Have you had any imaging studies of your brain, such as an MRI or CT scan?
Yes, an MRI of my brain was obtained.
**Final Diagnosis:** Juvenile Huntington's disease

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 17-year-old individual is experiencing memory and attention difficulties and woke up feeling disoriented about their location. They also noticed slow jerking movements on one side of their body and have been experiencing poor memory and attention. The individual's maternal grandfather has Huntington disease. The individual's mother mentioned their recent lack of attention and memory issues. They have been to the emergency room for a physical examination and received an MRI of their brain.
trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Possible onset of Alzheimer's disease
